answers.text:
Hi Rosylen, 
Thanks for reaching out to us for help with your problem. In looking on the Retirement topic page, I came across a report on pension funding called “Pension Funding: A guide for Elected Officials” that provides key facts about public pension plans, and offers guidance on developing pension funding policies.  (http://icma.org/en/icma/priorities/public_policy/policy_priorities/pension_funding) 
The Center For State and Local Government Excellence also has a report, called “The Evolving Role of Defined Contribution Plans in the Public Sector,” that discusses funding policies. (http://slge.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/The-Evolving-Role-of-Defined-Contribution-Plans.pdf) 
David Gassaway of the City of Rancho Cordova, CA took a look at how pensions based on combined contributions relate to pensions based on defined benefits, and his findings can also be found on the Retirement topic page. (http://icma.org/en/Article/101835/Pension_Reform_A_Look_at_Defined_Contribution_DC_vs_Defined_Benefit_DB_Systems) 
Please feel free to reach out to us again if you need any help answering questions or finding resources. 
Aloha, 
James Davidson 
Knowledge Network Intern

author: Rosylen Oglesby
text: I am conducting a research of localities that manage their own municipal retirement systems.  I would like to know what these localities use as part of its calculation for its retirees other than the base salary.  For example, do you use clothing allowances, specialize training certifications, or on-call/overtime as part of the calculations.
title: Retirement Benefit Calculation for Municipal Owned Retirement Systems
